title: Foreign policy of the Joe Biden administration
Foreign policy of the Joe Biden administration
Foreign policy of the Joe Biden administration
added: On January 23, 2021, Biden and [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom]], [[Boris Johnson]], had a phone call.<ref>{{cite news |title=UK's Johnson says he looks forward to working with Biden on shared goals |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-biden-britain-johnson-idUSKBN29S0OI |access-date=23 January 2021 |work=Reuters |date=23 January 2021}}</ref> As the [[United Kingdom]] has gained independence and control over its trade policy after the completion of [[Brexit]], Prime Minister Johnson pushed Biden for a new trade deal that would unite a global response the [[COVID-19 Pandemic]]. Both [[White House Press Secretary]] [[Jen Psaki]] and [[United States Secretary of the Treasury]]-designate [[Janet Yellen]] have signaled that the [[Presidency of Joe Biden|Biden administration]] is unlikely to push for a trade deal early on in the Biden's term.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Madhani |first1=Aamer |title=Britain’s Boris Johnson presses Biden for new trade deal |url=https://apnews.com/article/joe-biden-global-trade-health-coronavirus-pandemic-jen-psaki-332faf002eb52c7db6429704b7c8ff9b |access-date=23 January 2021 |work=Associated Press |date=23 January 2021}}</ref>

title: Foreign policy of the Joe Biden administration
added: On January 24, 2021, Biden met with [[President of France]] [[Emmanuel Macron]].<ref>{{cite journal |title=Readout of President Joseph R. Biden, Jr. Call with President Emmanuel Macron of France |journal=The White House |date=24 January 2021 |url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/statements-releases/2021/01/24/readout-of-president-joseph-r-biden-jr-call-with-president-emmanuel-macron-of-france/ |access-date=25 January 2021}}</ref> On the call, Biden spoke of strengthening bilateral ties with [[France]] and bolstering transatlantic relations through [[NATO]] and the [[European Union]]. Both Biden and Macron agreed that they need close coordination on issues such as [[climate change]], the [[COVID-19 pandemic]] and [[Multilateralism|multilateral organizations]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Zengerle |first1=Patricia |title=Biden speaks with France's Macron, seeks to strengthen ties |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-france/biden-speaks-with-frances-macron-seeks-to-strengthen-ties-idUSKBN29T0QI |access-date=25 January 2021 |work=Reuters |date=24 January 2021}}</ref>

title: Foreign policy of the Joe Biden administration
added: <ref>{{cite press-release|url=https://www.state.gov/prioritizing-sexual-and-reproductive-health-and-reproductive-rights-in-u-s-foreign-policy/|title=Prioritizing sexual and reproductive health and reproductive rights in US foreign policy}}</ref>

title: Foreign policy of the Joe Biden administration
Foreign policy of the Joe Biden administration
deleted: On February 1, 2021, Biden condemned the [[2021 Myanmar coup d'état|Myanmar coup d'état]] and called for the release of detained officials. Biden also threatened to impose sanctions on coup perpetrators, saying in a statement that the United States would initiate "an immediate review of our sanction laws and authorities, followed by appropriate action." <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/statements-releases/2021/01/31/statement-by-white-house-spokesperson-jen-psaki-on-burma/|title=Statement by White House Spokesperson Jen Psaki on Burma|date=1 February 2021|website=The White House}}</ref><ref>{{Cite tweet |user=ZekeJMiller |number=1356293569674440704 |title=Biden statement on Burma: "The United States removed sanctions on Burma over the past decade based on progress toward democracy. The reversal of that progress will necessitate an immediate review of our sanction laws and authorities, followed by appropriate action."

title: Foreign policy of the Joe Biden administration
Foreign policy of the Joe Biden administration
added: Biden reinstated the [[Foreign policy of Donald Trump|Trump administration's]] travel bans on several parts of the world, including the [[Schengen Area]], the [[Republic of Ireland]], the [[United Kingdom]], and [[Brazil]]. He also added [[South Africa]] to the list of countries on January 25, 2021.<ref>{{cite news |title=Biden adds South Africa to Covid travel bans |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-55805428 |access-date=25 January 2021 |work=BBC News |publisher=BBC |date=25 January 2021}}</ref>

title: Foreign policy of the Joe Biden administration
Foreign policy of the Joe Biden administration
added: On February 4, 2021, Biden announced he would freeze the Trump administration's withdrawal of 9,500 troops from American military bases in Berlin, Germany.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Gearan|first=Anne|last2=Hudson|first2=John|last3=Ryan|first3=Missy|date=February 4, 2021|title=U.S. ending support for Saudi-led war in Yemen as Biden shifts foreign policy priorities|language=en-US|work=[[The Washington Post]]|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/biden-yemen-saudi-war-support/2021/02/04/ae61c14a-670d-11eb-8468-21bc48f07fe5_story.html|url-status=live|access-date=2021-02-04|issn=0190-8286}}</ref>

title: Foreign policy of the Joe Biden administration
added: Mexican President López Obrador said that President Biden has pledged $4 billion for development in [[Honduras]], [[El Salvador]], and [[Guatemala]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=STEVENSON |first1=MARK |last2=GILLIES |first2=ROB |last3=MADHANI |first3=AAMER |title=Mexican leader says Biden offers $4B for Central America |url=https://www.yahoo.com/news/biden-calls-canadas-trudeau-mexicos-153700432.html |access-date=January 24, 2021 |work=news.yahoo.com |agency=AP |date=January 23, 2021}}</ref> Secretary of State Antony Blinken said on February 6 that agreements with those three countries to send asylum-seekers back to those countries until their cases were heard were suspended.<ref>{{cite news |title=US to end deals to send asylum seekers back to Central America |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/2/6/us-to-end-deals-to-send-asylum-seekers-to-central-america |access-date=February 6, 2021 |work=aljazeera.com |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=February 6, 2021 |language=en}}</ref>

title: Foreign policy of the Joe Biden administration
added: Biden held a telephone call with [[Prime Minister of India|Indian Prime Minister]] [[Narendra Modi]] on February 8, 2021.

title: Foreign policy of the Joe Biden administration
added: Biden held his first telephone calls with [[Xi Jinping]] on February 10. 2021.{{expand section|date=February 2021}}
